16.47.text:
When you are in a relationship,
when do you say,

18.77.text: "I love you," for the first time?

21.26.text: How do you know you are in love?

23.40.text: When do you define the relationship?

25.58.text: When do you make it 'Facebook official'?

30.30.text: We all know the symptoms of love:

32.74.text:
the butterflies in your stomach,
your hands getting clammy,

40.12.text: but you cannot wait for more.

43.13.text:
There's a lot going on
when you fall in love.

45.30.text:
You thought it was just a bunch
of heartache and money.

48.60.text:
Your brain goes through
all kinds of changes.

51.19.text:
It gets flooded with oxytocin,
the love chemical.

58.75.text:
On the other hand,
since the time you could walk,

61.79.text:
you've heard stories
about love from everyone.

65.74.text:
Is the ability to fall in love
genetically programmed

69.52.text: or were you conditioned to fall in love?

72.25.text: Is it nature or is it nurture?

76.88.text:
What exactly do we mean
by "Nature vs. Nurture"?

80.19.text:
By "Nature" we mean things
that are genetically programmed,

83.62.text: passed down from generation to generation,

86.41.text:
apart from a fluke mutation
once in a while.

90.00.text:
By "Nurture" we mean
things that are learnt,

92.48.text:
or a product of your environment,
like riding a bike,

95.81.text:
or maybe staying in the sun
too long and getting skin cancer.

100.59.text: How about the ability to deal with stress?

104.17.text:
Is that genetically programmed,
or a product of your environment?

109.09.text:
How about gender identity?
Nature or Nurture?

113.19.text: How about the ability to annoy people?

117.36.text:
Don't you just want to ask
that annoying person at work:

120.12.text:
"Were you genetically programmed
to be that way?"

123.63.text:
"Or do you actually practice that
in front of the mirror all day?"

129.96.text: Some traits are not nature and not nurture

133.99.text:
but something different
all together: epigenetic.

139.12.text:
Epigenetics literally means
a layer above your genetics.

143.36.text: If your genetics is the hardware,

145.84.text:
your epigenetics is the software,
or the operating system.

150.47.text:
Your epigenetics allows
the environment to change your DNA.

155.64.text:
The most famous example
of epigenetics is the response to stress.

161.26.text:
A group in Montreal used rats
to go after the specific question:

165.67.text:
"If you are an attentive mom, does
that affect the DNA of your children?"

171.56.text: They looked at two populations of rats.

175.89.text:
the mothers were very nurturing,
licking and grooming their pups.

179.75.text:
These baby rats actually
have the royal treatment.

182.78.text:
Mom's cuddling them
all the time, tying their shoes,

185.49.text: driving them to soccer practice every day.

188.84.text: These baby rats had it made.

191.54.text:
They looked at the DNA of these baby rats,
and the DNA looked fine.

196.60.text:
In population number 2
these mothers were not very nurturing.

201.27.text:
No licking, no grooming,
no cuddling. Not very attentive.

205.26.text: They looked at the DNA of these baby rats

208.30.text: and they found strange marks on that DNA,

212.09.text:
and those marks were positioned
precisely at the stress response gene.

217.78.text:
In fact, these baby rats
couldn't deal with any stress at all.

222.05.text:
And that behavior persisted
for their whole lifetime.

226.05.text:
For kicks, they decided
to look at the grandkids' DNA.

229.86.text:
And the grandkids' stress response gene
was turned off too.

237.19.text:
How can a mother nurturing
her pups change their DNA?

243.54.text: Let's think about what DNA is.

247.98.text: that's very thin and very long.

251.78.text: There is enough DNA in your body

254.37.text:
to wrap around the Earth
2.5 million times.

259.57.text:
How can all that DNA
be squeezed into your body

263.47.text:
in such an organized way
to control everything?

273.87.text: trillions and trillions of these spools.

277.58.text:
Here we can see DNA
in all its glory, atom for atom.

287.80.text:
At first, the stress response
is turned off.

290.63.text:
But when our baby rats
are being hugged and cuddled,

294.57.text: serotonin is released in their brains.

297.90.text: Serotonin turns on a light switch,

303.52.text: This is chemically modified, or acylated,

306.45.text:
triggering the spools to unwind,
unwrapping the DNA,

310.83.text:
exposing the stress response
part to the cell.

314.78.text: So our baby rats are happy and healthy.

318.49.text: You can think of it like a garden hose.

321.48.text: Imagine a garden hose a mile long,

324.62.text: here in this theater, floating in the air.

328.77.text:
Do you know those garden hose spools,
the plastic ones,

334.52.text:
Imagine thousands of those spools
winding and unwinding,

338.45.text:
turning genes on and off
with exquisite precision.

342.75.text: Somehow, these spools have special powers.

346.85.text:
They know what is happening
all around the cell.

350.49.text: They can turn the genes on and off

352.79.text:
at just the right times,
at just the right moments.

358.85.text:
they can take an egg cell
to an embryo to a newborn baby.

363.48.text:
So our molecular spools are winding
and unwinding, controlling everything,

367.48.text:
like the maestro of a big dance,
or better yet, a DJ.

371.80.text:
If our hose were actually
the color green and glowing,

375.49.text:
then we'd actually have
a real rave party in here.

379.65.text:
♪ Boots and pants and boots and pants
and boots and pants and boots and pants ♪

397.58.text: a big rave party in your cells,

399.87.text:
where DNA and socialization
get all tangled up together.

408.69.text: Was I born a girl or did I become one?

416.32.text:
almost every romantic relationship
that I've been in.

420.63.text:
You see, I am a woman
who happens to be transgender.

428.28.text:
until I finally found the courage
to be who I really am.

444.69.text: If you think love is complicated,

446.68.text: imagine what it is like for me;

449.19.text:
about as complicated
as that DNA molecule we're looking at.

452.84.text:
Luckily, both of my parents
nurtured me all the time,

457.03.text:
so I have plenty of serotonin
stored up to deal with stress

460.56.text:
and to be here,
on this stage, coming out.

467.24.text: I've been following in the footsteps

469.29.text:
of Laverne Cox, Geena Rocero
and Janet Mock.

472.58.text:
Back when I was in therapy,
my therapist mentioned:

476.10.text:
"If you could identify
the genetic basis of gender dysphoria,

480.03.text: it would be a real breakthrough."

482.00.text: She actually used the word rockstar,

483.78.text: and who does not want to be a rockstar?

486.69.text:
At the time, I was working
in the field of RNA.

494.16.text: So, I sat down and I googled,

501.28.text:
There was only one hit,
"steroid receptor RNA activator."

507.10.text: This helps estrogen do its thing.

509.13.text:
It also directly binds
the sex reversal factor.

513.50.text: I went to my postdoc, Irina.

516.01.text:
"I've got this RNA molecule
and no one has really heard of it.

519.36.text:
It is so big, it's going to be
almost impossible to study.

522.13.text: How about this for your new project?"

527.90.text:
To set the stage, remember
our molecular spools?

532.80.text: Somehow they knew what was happening,

534.59.text: always in right place, at the right time.

537.70.text:
How do these spools
know what's going on?

541.28.text:
Groups around the world
are racing to figure this out.

545.24.text: Many think that it could be RNA.

549.29.text:
You see, RNA molecules
can sense their environment.

552.97.text: They can bind drugs and vitamins.

556.67.text:
If our big RNA molecule
were highly structured,

560.19.text: it could actually talk to those spools,

562.32.text:
telling them what's happening
all around the cell.

565.09.text:
Like: "Yikes, it's freezing
in this part of the cell."

568.66.text:
Or: "Mmm, caffeine
in this part of the cell."

571.72.text:
Or: "Run for your life.
It's a sperm molecule."

583.92.text:
if our big RNA had no structure,
like a bowl of spaghetti,

588.06.text:
then all that it could say to the spool
would be gobbledygook,

591.11.text:
like: "Bo tosh beer job blue Dee
ray ahh cock kook nay."

597.55.text:
That was the Klingon language
from Star Trek, but you get the idea.

605.57.text: In the end, this is what we found.

607.56.text:
Our big RNA molecule
had structure everywhere.

611.30.text:
25 helices in all,
all kinds of interactions.

615.88.text: This is just a baby step,

617.82.text:
but it's a proof of principle
that RNA could be the answer.

622.48.text:
RNA molecules have been shown
to have links to Alzheimer's and autism,

627.44.text:
and epigenetic effects,
in general, have strong ties

634.87.text:
Ten years ago, we couldn't fathom
how these could be.

638.80.text: Now, we are taking the first steps.

642.14.text: Some day, we might understand love,

645.90.text: which brings us back to our question:

648.02.text: how do you know you are in love?

652.46.text:
but maybe in the future,
when your kids ask you:

655.25.text: "How do you know you're in love?"
